languagesAndFrameworks.label: Vue.js
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Vue.js is a lightweight and pragmatic approach to single-page applications that gets out of your way and just works.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Nuxt.js
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Nuxt.js takes the last pieces boilerplate off your shoulders. Manual implementation of your authentication, the routing and recurring http error handling belong to the past.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Kotlin
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Kotlin is Java on steroids. Data classes, immutability by default, null safety and extension functions are just a few real-world productivity features that already saved us hours of work.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: jOOQ
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Complex relations and heavy duty SQL are not a good match for ORMs (see JPA on 'Hold'). jOOQ is a typesafe SQL DSL for the java ecosystem that works best where you are not dealing with simple CRUD.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Spring Boot
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Spring Boot makes Spring more accessible to the newbie Spring developer and gets out of the way for the experienced developer. It comes with autoconfiguration with sensible defaults, monitoring and logging solutions and embedded servlet container out of the box. Many third party tools and frameworks (databases, message queues, email, you name it) are already supported or can easily be adapted. Spring Boot is our go to framework for building standalone or microservice systems.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Spring Integration for MQTT
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Spring Integration is a fantastic tool for some use cases. In our case, however, we experienced serious performance problems when we used it in a high-volume application.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Testcontainers
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Testcontainers is part of our toolkit to ensure the quality of our applications within our continuous deployment pipelines.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Spock
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Spock served us well in times of Java. Using Spock with Kotlin is cumbersome (e.g. no copy() methods), so we prefer vanilla JUnit. We miss data tables very much though... :-(

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Springdoc
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: Springdoc java library helps to automate the generation of API documentation using spring boot projects. We use this for our publicly available http interfaces.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: Thymeleaf
languagesAndFrameworks.reason:
Thymeleaf is a server-side rendered Java templating engine. It's focus is on templates that can be rendered by browsers even though no backend server is running. This sounds promising as a UI designer can work independently from development.
In our project where we used it, this never happened. UX design and frontend development was done at the same time by the same person. So the templates are not so concise as they could be.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: JPA
languagesAndFrameworks.reason: JPA or ORM in general can be quite the hassle for complex data models and heavy duty SQL due to the Object-Relation Impedance Mismatch. Ted Neward once called it the Vietnam of Computer Science for this exact reason. Since we usually don't build simple CRUD systems, JPA is rarely a good solution.

languagesAndFrameworks.label: GraphQL
languagesAndFrameworks.reason:
GraphQL is a query language for your APIs. Opposing to REST calls this technology allows the client to customize the requests and ask for the required information based on a query. The execution side on the backend (resolvers) is fully decoupled from the requesting side.
This sounds like a promising tool when providing an application that needs a more flexible interface between frontend and backend.

dataManagement.label: Hosted Broker
dataManagement.reason: Operating a distributed message broker is an arduous task that demands a significant amount of time. We have reached a juncture where we no longer wish to continue managing it ourselves and, if feasible, would prefer utilizing hosted brokers.

dataManagement.label: PostgreSQL
dataManagement.reason: PostgreSQL is an object-relational database system. It has a nice 🐘.

infrastructure.label: Kustomize
infrastructure.reason: Although kustomize is low-tech and easy to use, it becomes complex and error-prone for non-trivial deployments.

infrastructure.label: Teamcity
infrastructure.reason: Teamcity served us well over the years, but newer projects are using Github Actions, which is easier to maintain and more fun to use.

infrastructure.label: Github Actions
infrastructure.reason: Moving away from Teamcity, because Github Actions is easier to maintain and integrates well with the whole Github eco system (e.g. packages).

infrastructure.label: Hosted IAM
infrastructure.reason: We lately moved over to hosted identity management because it seems to be more cost efficient than self-hosted services (depends on the size of course).

infrastructure.label: Digital Ocean
infrastructure.reason: We run most of our projects using digital ocean services like managed clusters, databases, apps and spaces.

infrastructure.label: Cloud Native Development
infrastructure.reason: We experiment with cloud native development to reduce our operation costs.

infrastructure.label: Grafana Stack
infrastructure.reason: Including Loki, Prometheus and Grafana. Using more tools is planned in the future.

tools.label: Maven
tools.reason:
Apache Maven is a solid, well proven and highly extensible build tool used in the Java ecosystem.
It is tedious to write and has a build lifecycle with phases no sane person can fully grasp. But it does the job.

tools.label: AI Assistants
tools.reason: There are many AI assistants available and the space is evolving rapidly. Currently ChatGPT, Claude, GitHub Copilot and IntelliJ Junie are the most popular with us.
